Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 25: The attainment of the unsurpassable wisdom of perfect awakening.

During the first watch of the night, the Bodhisattva dwelt in a state of equanimity and relying on [the concentration of] the extreme limits, acquired the ability to work miracles as well as the divine ear.
Manual - English: Although it is the same night when the Buddha tames the demon and becomes the Buddha, there is a major difference, so there is no need to draw the Buddha achieving enlightenment in a separate scene. The Buddha sits in equanimity on the grass mattress under the Bodhi Tree. His body radiates infinite rays of light.

Sun of Faith - English: In the course of the second watch, he acquired the powers of knowing others' thoughts, of remembering previous lives, and the divine eye.
During the third vigil, he gained the "extrasensory perception of the exhaustion of all contaminations”
Having reached perfect awakening, he became an omniscient buddha.
The demons of the House of Shadows went to Kapilavastu to spread rumours about the Bodhisattva’s death and in this way sowed deep grief among the entire populace.
But to everyone’s joy, the gods quickly countered: “Shakyamuni, Tamer of the Shakyas, is not dead. Indeed, he has just achieved the perfect wisdom that accompanies genuine buddhahood.”
In that way the Bhagavan found perfect wisdom on the full moon night (sa ga'i zla wa) of the fifth [lunar] month.
Indeed, in that same month, there was a lunar eclipse,
and Rahula (Sgra gcan zin), son of Yaśodharā [the former wife of Siddhārtha] came into the world along with Ānanda (Kun dga’ bo), son of Amrtodana (Bdud rtsi za) [Siddhārtha’s uncle].
A dazzling light flooded all of space, bathing dark corners as well as the natural obstacles that create shadows between different regions of the earth.
[To commemorate that night] Kapilavastu’s citizens had a pavilion built and filled it with gracious gifts and started to share their riches, practise meritorious deeds and make huge food offerings.
Having achieved perfect buddhahood, the Tathagata Bhagavan, Tamer of the Shakyas, remained in meditation, [now] meditating on the element of fire
and continued to sit thus, unmoving, in the diamond posture, for seven days and seven nights.
